{{Self-published|date=May 2008}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = InternetNZ | image = | type = Non-profit | founded_date = | tax_id = | registration_id = | founder = | location = Level 11, 80 Boulcott Street, [[Wellington, New Zealand]]<ref>[https://internetnz.nz/contact-us Contact]</ref> | coordinates = | origins = | key_people = Chief Executive: Jordan Carter, Council President: Jamie Baddeley | area_served = New Zealand | product = | mission = Protection, promotion of the [[Internet]] in New Zealand | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = New Zealand Domain Name Registry Limited, Domain Name Commission Limited | owner = | non-profit_slogan = | former name = | homepage = {{URL|http://internetnz.net.nz/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''InternetNZ''' ("Internet New Zealand Inc." and originally formed as the '''Internet Society of New Zealand''') is a not-for-profit open membership organisation dedicated to protecting and promoting the Internet for New Zealand. Its vision is for a better world through a better Internet and it promotes the Internet’s benefits and protect its potential. InternetNZ focuses on advancing an open and uncaptureable Internet for New Zealand.
It provides a voice for the Internet in New Zealand. It lobbies the government. And it gives a helping hand to Internet users across New Zealand.
InternetNZ is the designated manager for the .nz Internet domain, and through this role it represents New Zealand at a global level. It provides community funding to promote research and the discovery of ways to improve the Internet. It informs people about the Internet and ensures it is well understood by those making decisions that help shape it. Every year it brings the Internet community together at NetHui to share wisdom and best practice on the state of the Internet.
== Current Councillors ==
The elected InternetNZ council as at 26 July 2018 are Jamie Baddeley (President), Joy Liddicoat (Vice President), Sarah Lee, Kate Pearce, Dave Moskovitz, Richard Wood, Amber Craig, Kelly Buehler, Richard Hulse, Don Stokes, Kate Pearce, and Keith Davidson.<ref>{{cite web | title=InternetNZ Council | url=https://internetnz.nz/internetnz-council | accessdate=2015-02-25}}</ref>
== History == The Internet Society of New Zealand was originally formed in 1995 in order to take responsibility for the [[.nz]] [[ccTLD]].
At the annual meeting on 4 August 2008, InternetNZ's [[Peter Dengate Thrush]] was made an InternetNZ Fellow because of his record of contribution to Internet policy issues in New Zealand and internationally.<ref name="Dengate Thrush Fellow">{{cite web | title=Peter Dengate Thrush named InternetNZ Fellow | url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/SC0808/S00012.htm | accessdate=2008-08-25}}</ref>
===Relationship with Internet Society=== Despite sharing many aims with the [[Internet Society]], InternetNZ has never been a chapter of that organisation. In April 2008, the organisation formally changed its official name to "Internet New Zealand Inc." to recognise common usage and to specifically reflect these differences.<ref> {{cite web |title=InternetNZ proposes official name-change |date=2008-01-31 |url=http://computerworld.co.nz/news.nsf/news/ac58ae96cd262ed7cc2573db000d4ee6 |accessdate=2008-05-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411140021/http://computerworld.co.nz/news.nsf/news/AC58AE96CD262ED7CC2573DB000D4EE6 |archivedate=2008-04-11 |df= }} </ref> InternetNZ did, however, join the Internet Society in 2006 as an organisational member.<ref> {{cite web | title=ISOC Membership Organisation Members | date=2006-06-26 | url=http://www.isoc.org/isoc/general/trustees/docs/200606/pub_ISOC-BoT-Members-Jun06_v2.pdf | accessdate=2008-05-09 }} </ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== See also == * http://internetnz.net.nz/ The official website * http://nethistory.co.nz/ A history of the Internet in New Zealand, written by Keith Newman.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Internetnz}} [[Category:Internet governance organizations]] [[Category:Internet in New Zealand]] [[Category:Business organisations based in New Zealand]]

'''Jan Justus Enschedé''' (1807 in [[Haarlem]] – 1887 in Haarlem)<ref name="NNBW">P.C. Molhuysen en P.J. Blok (red.), [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/molh003nieu04_01/molh003nieu04_01_0893.php Nieuw Nederlandsch biografisch woordenboek. Deel 1] (Dutch) Jan Justus Enschedé (3)</ref> was a newspaper editor and printer in Haarlem, the Netherlands.
==Biography== He was the great great grandson of the founder of the [[Joh. Enschedé]] company, and the son of [[Jacobus Enschedé II]]. Like his second cousin and mentor [[Johannes Enschedé III]], he was a member of the [[Dutch Society of Science]] and the [[Teylers Second Society]]. He worked for Enschedé III as editor of the [[Opregte Haarlemsche Courant]] from 1829, later joined by [[Johannes Enschedé IV]]. In 1850 they had a quarrel with the city council of Haarlem over the use of the [[Coat of arms of Haarlem|city coat of arms]] in the newspaper. As city publisher they had the right, but Haarlem withdrew this privilege, claiming ownership. Jan Justus wrote a book explaining the case of Enschedé, which they won.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ifFQAAAAcAAJ Bedenkingen tegen de adviezen van mr. B. Donker Curtius en mr. G. de Vries Az., omtrent het eigendomsregt der Opregte Haarlemsche Courant] by Jan Justus Enschedé on [[Google books]]</ref> In the 1860s the paper was considered the best in the country and attracted editors such as [[Conrad Busken Huet]] and [[Multatuli]].
==References== {{reflist}} * Enschede aan het Klokhuisplein, (Dutch), by Just Enschede, De Vrieseborch, Haarlem, 1991, {{ISBN|9060763416}}

Enschedé]] [[Category:19th-century journalists]] [[Category:Male journalists]] [[Category:19th-century male writers]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Jonathan A. Kraft | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|3|4}} | birth_place = [[Brookline, Massachusetts]] | residence = | nationality = American | occupation = Businessman | known_for = President of [[The Kraft Group]]
President of the [[New England Patriots]] | spouse = Patricia Lipoma | children = | parents = [[Myra Kraft]]
[[Robert Kraft]] | ethnicity = | alma mater = B.A. [[Williams College]]
M.B.A. [[Harvard Business School]] | networth = }} '''Jonathan A. Kraft''' (born March 4, 1964) is an American [[businessman]]. He is president of [[The Kraft Group]], the holding company of the Kraft family's many business interests. He is also the [[president]] of the [[New England Patriots]] and owner/investor of the [[New England Revolution]].{{cite web | url=http://www.jspace.com/news/articles/jewish-owners-face-off-in-super-bowl-xlvi/7386 | title=Jewish Owners Face Off in Super Bowl XLVI | publisher=Jspace | date=February 4, 2012 | author=Jspace Staf | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125020601/http://www.jspace.com/news/articles/jewish-owners-face-off-in-super-bowl-xlvi/7386 | archivedate=January 25, 2013 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/sports/article/bob_kraft_new_england_patriots_jewish_owner_20120123/ | title=Bob Kraft: New England Patriots’ Jewish owner | publisher=Jewish Journal | date=January 23, 2012 | accessdate=September 13, 2012 | author=Andrew Gershman}} ==Early life and education== Kraft was born in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], to a [[American Jewish|Jewish]] family, one of four children of [[New England Patriots]] owner [[Robert Kraft]] and his late wife [[Myra Kraft]]. Robert Kraft is worth an estimated $4.8 billion, according to Forbes and ranks as 108th richest person in 2015.{{Cite web|title = Robert Kraft|url = https://www.forbes.com/profile/robert-kraft/|website = Forbes|access-date = 2016-01-12}} Kraft attended the [[Belmont Hill School]] for high school. In 1986, Kraft graduated from [[Williams College]] with a [[Bachelor of Arts|bachelor's degree]] in [[history]]. He currently serves on Williams' [[board of trustees]]. After working as a consultant at [[Bain & Company]] for two years, Kraft earned his [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]] in 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.highpoint-capital.com/team.html|title=HighPoint Capital Team Members|work=HighPoint Capital|accessdate=2007-06-03}} ==Professional career== ===New England Patriots=== Since his family's purchase of the team in 1994, Kraft has held the titles of Vice President (1994–1999), Vice Chairman (2000–2005) and President (2005–present), and thus has overseen the management of each department in the organization. ====Role with the NFL==== Within the [[National Football League]], Kraft serves on two owners' committees. In March [[2006 NFL season|2006]], when the [[National Football League Players Association]] and the NFL were deadlocked in contract negotiations, Kraft designed the revenue sharing plan that was used for that version of the [[collective bargaining agreement]]. ===New England Revolution=== Since their inception in 1995 as one of the inaugural teams of [[Major League Soccer]], Kraft has been the co-owner/investor of the Revolution, along with his father. Foxboro hosted its third [[MLS Cup]] in 2002, the first in Gillette Stadium and the first involving the Revolution as one of the teams vying for the MLS title. In front of an MLS-record crowd of 61,136, the Revolution would go on to lose the match, as well as their other four MLS Cup appearances in 2005, 2006, 2007, and 2014. ====Other soccer involvements==== The Krafts' interest in soccer has extended beyond the Revolution. [[Foxboro Stadium]] played host to six matches of the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]], five of the [[FIFA Women's World Cup 1999|1999 FIFA Women's World Cup]], as well as the [[Women's United Soccer Association|2000 Founder's Cup]]. In November 2005, the Krafts expressed interest in purchasing the [[Liverpool F.C.]],{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/4420306.stm|title=Kraft admits Liverpool interest|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2005-11-14|accessdate=2007-06-05}} but the team was eventually acquired by a pair including [[Tom Hicks]], the owner of the [[Dallas Stars]] and [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]], in February 2007.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/6323037.stm|title=US pair agree Liverpool takeover|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2007-02-06|accessdate=2007-06-05}} Kraft also served as the owner/investor of the [[San Jose Earthquakes]] from 1999–2000, the two years which the Kraft Group owned the team. ==Personal life== He has 3 children, two sons and a daughter. In 1995, Kraft married Patricia Lipoma in a Jewish ceremony at the [[Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts|Chestnut Hill]] home of his parents. She is a convert to [[Judaism]].[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-8332878.html Boston Globe: "A Patriotic wedding" by Susan Bickelhaupt and Ellen O'Brien] June 20, 1995 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130910040422/http://www.patriots.com/team/staff/jonathan-kraft/82548dfc-9f29-47f8-a508-6ccf7844a6ef New England Patriots profile] * [http://www.thekraftgroup.com/ The Kraft Group] {{New England Patriots}} {{New England Patriots president navbox}} {{NFL president navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kraft, Jonathan}} [[Category:1964 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:American corporate directors]] [[Category:American financiers]] [[Category:American manufacturing businesspeople]] [[Category:American media executives]] [[Category:American people of Lithuanian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American real estate businesspeople]] [[Category:American soccer chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Bain & Company employees]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Massachusetts]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Jewish American sportspeople]] [[Category:Kraft family]] [[Category:Major League Soccer executives]] [[Category:National Football League team presidents]] [[Category:New England Patriots executives]] [[Category:New England Revolution]] [[Category:People from Brookline, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Williams College alumni]] [[Category:Belmont Hill School alumni]]

{{Infobox University |name = The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center |image = Lavin Entrepreneurship Center Logo.gif |image_size = 220px |motto = ''Fuel for Entrepreneurs'' |established = 1986 |director= Alex F. DeNoble |campus = [[San Diego State University]] |city = [[San Diego]] |state = [[California]] |country = U.S. |website= {{url|lavincenter.sdsu.edu}} |former_names = Entrepreneurial Management Center }}
The '''Lavin Entrepreneurship Center''' is housed within the [[San Diego State University College of Business Administration|College of Business Administration]] at [[San Diego State University]] (SDSU) and offers a blend of university curriculum and experiential learning opportunities to students across the SDSU campus. The Center provides academic curriculum through both a major and minor in entrepreneurship and hands-on learning opportunities through various co-curricular programs. The Lavin Center is a resource for SDSU students that provides an entrepreneurial foundation and encourages innovation.<ref name="aboutthelavinentrepreneurshipcenter">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/about/ "About the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center"]</ref>
The mission of the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center is "to inspire entrepreneurship campus-wide and enable students to develop the entrepreneurial competencies necessary to compete in the global economy."<ref>http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/</ref>
== History == San Diego State University management professor emeritus, Dr. Daryl Mitton, formed the University’s original Entrepreneurial Management Center (EMC) in 1980. In 1986, the EMC received its first funding and the program has been dedicated to entrepreneurial research and development since.<ref name="emccelebrates25years">[http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/~cba/news-online/11-July/f.html "EMC Celebrates 25 Years"] College of Business Administration News. Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref>
In 2012, the Entrepreneurial Management Center was renamed to honor [[Leonard H. Lavin|Dr. Leonard H. Lavin]], founder of the [[Alberto-Culver]] company and a longtime supporter of the Center. Dr. Lavin has been actively involved with the Center as a guest lecturer and mentor since 2005.<ref name="entrepreneurialmanagementcenternamed">[http://newscenter.sdsu.edu/sdsu_newscenter/news.aspx?s=73955 "Entrepreneurial Management Center Named"] Business Administration Story. Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref>
== Entrepreneurship Curriculum == The SDSU College of Business Administration works closely with the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center to offer a curriculum designed to meet the needs of students with an interest in entrepreneurship. The blend of academic and experiential learning is geared to provide students with a theoretical foundation as well as build and reinforce lifelong skills necessary to succeed as an entrepreneur.<ref name="lavincurriculum">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/curriculum/ "Lavin Curriculum"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref>
=== Undergraduate Program ===
The Undergraduate Entrepreneurship curriculum is designed so that students who wish to have deep immersion in entrepreneurship can do so through the specialization, while students – from both a business and non-business background – seeking some exposure to the entrepreneurial mindset can do so through the minor.
* '''Specialization in Entrepreneurship:''' The Specialization in Entrepreneurship is crafted specifically for Management majors in the College of Business Administration. This specialization complements the managing theories and strategies in the core classes with an innovational and an entrepreneurial mindset. In this specialization, students have the opportunity to explore the ins-and-outs of family business, franchising, international and social ventures, as well as creativity and innovation.<ref name="entrepreneurshipspecialization">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/curriculum/management_specialization.php "Entrepreneurship Specialization"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''Minor in Entrepreneurship:''' The Entrepreneurship Minor is open to all students enrolled at SDSU, regardless of academic major. Through the entrepreneurship minor, both business and non-business students have the opportunity to learn how to take an idea, evaluate it, and potentially turn it into a real business.
=== Graduate Program ===
The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center supports the SDSU graduate program in entrepreneurship and acts as a physical hub on campus as well as a virtual web community that allows entrepreneurs, investors, and service providers to partner with one another and provide resources for start-up companies.
The case study lead curriculum is taught in an environment where students work in teams. Students are encouraged to think strategically, learn how to assess ideas and solutions, build appropriate financial and business models, and develop the right management and marketing strategies. The faculty in the program are a blend of tenured professors and industry experienced lecturers to provide a balance of theory and application.<ref name="lavingraduateprogram">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/curriculum/grad.php "Lavin Graduate Program"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref>
== Lavin Entrepreneurship Center Programs == The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center offers a wide range of co-curricular programs for SDSU students. Some of the programs available through the Center include:<ref name="lavincenterprograms">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/ "Lavin Center Programs"] Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref>
*'''Lavin Center Internship Program:''' The Lavin Center's internship program provides graduate students with the opportunity to engage with an organization in the community through both for-profit and non-profit internships. MBA and other graduate interns take part in the development of short and long-term strategy, competitive marketplace due diligence, and the research and final recommendations for action. Strategic projects range from operations, finance, and management to business development, research and marketing.<ref name="lavincenterinternships">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Internships/ "Lavin Center Internships"] Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref> *'''The Lavin Entrepreneur Program:''' The Lavin Entrepreneur program recruits sophomore students, from all SDSU colleges, to participate in a two-year program that provides them with an experience designed to prepare them for an entrepreneurial career. The aim of the program is to teach participants how to identify and evaluate new business opportunities, understand the roles and responsibilities of an entrepreneur, and how to marshal and deploy resources in order to launch and build new ventures.<ref name="lavinventurestart">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Lavin-VentureStart/ "Lavin VentureStart Page"] Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref> * '''Entrepreneur Day:''' The Lavin Center hosts Entrepreneur Day on the SDSU campus as a way to bring together alumni and student-run companies to celebrate a mutual passion for entrepreneurship. The event provides an outlet where students and alumni can present and showcase their business ideas. Thousands of students and community members attend the event. Alumni and student-founded companies promote their brand, sell their products, and energize customers with the spirit of entrepreneurship.<ref name="entrepreneurday">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/entrepreneur-day "Entrepreneur Day"] Retrieved November 4, 2013.</ref> * '''Start-up @ State:''' Start-up @ State is a two part event that brings local start-ups to the SDSU campus and presents students with the opportunity to interact directly with company founders. Students ask questions and hear directly from founders. In addition to the speaker engagement, attendees are invited to the Parma Payne Goodall Alumni Center where they are exposed to a number of start-ups all looking to hire students.<ref name="start-upatstate">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/StartUp@State/ "Start-up at State"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''WebCompass Internship:''' The Lavin Center’s WebCompass Internship is an undergraduate program that involves three colleges at SDSU. The semester-long internship involves teams consisting of students from business, graphic/web design, and computer science who work to complete a website-based project for San Diego non-profits. The goal is for students to learn to work cross functionally and build a brand for emerging companies using websites and social media.<ref name=webcompassinternship>[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Web-Compass/ "WebCompass Internship"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''L. Robert Payne Lecture Series:''' The lecture series brings entrepreneurs to SDSU to speak to and interact with students, faculty, and invited business representatives from the regional entrepreneurial community. The series was established in 1996 following a gift from SDSU alumnus L. Robert Payne, a long-time supporter of the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center.<ref name="lrobertpayne">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Thom-McElroy-Series/ "L. Robert Payne Series"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''SDGE Program:''' The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center partners with San Diego Gas & Electric to provide Strategic Growth Planning for Entrepreneurs Program. This is a 43-hour course-based program open to Diverse Business Enterprises (DBEs), which includes owners and senior managers of women-, minority-, and service disabled veteran-owned businesses in Southern California. The program is designed to attempt to assist DBEs with the development of strategic objectives to improve and grow their businesses.<ref name="sdgeprogram">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/sdge/ "SDGE Program"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''Entrepreneurship Conference:''' The primary focus of the California Entrepreneurship Conference's is to increase the interaction between university thought leaders and serve as a spring board for sharing entrepreneurial initiatives taking place on different campuses. Each session focuses on engaging interaction between conference participants.<ref name="entrepreneurshipconference">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Entrepreneurship-Conference/ "Entrepreneurship Conference"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref>
=== Business Plan Competitions ===
The Lavin Entrepreneurship Center hosts and has students participate in select business plan competitions. Students have the ability to pitch their start-up ideas to business professionals, receive feedback, and have the opportunity to receive financial and in-kind awards. Current competitions the Lavin Center are involved with include:
* '''Lavin VentureStart Competition:''' The VentureStart Competition is held every semester and is designed to encourage students on the SDSU campus to act on their talent, ideas, and energy. Students submit a business model canvas based on their ideas and four to five teams are selected to compete in the competition and present their business plan to a panel of entrepreneur judges. This business model competition cultivates ideas around lean startup and business model development to reward SDSU students for innovative ideation.<ref name="lavinventurestartcompetition">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/VentureStart-Competition/ "Lavin VentureStart Competition"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''LeanModel™ Competition:''' The LeanModel™ Competition is designed to assist and reward student based start-ups from California and Baja California's top four year universities. Students move quickly to develop a prototype, test their product on consumers, and pitch their start-up to potential investors while competing for awards to invest in their business. This competition encourages students to learn about the marketplace and focus on what consumers need based on the feedback.<ref name="leanmodelcompetition">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/Lean_Model/ "LeanModel Competition"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref> * '''Venture Capital Competition (VCIC):''' VCIC is a strategy competition for venture-minded and entrepreneurial MBA students who seek to learn about entrepreneurship from an investors prospective. Teams read business plans, meet CEOs, conduct an abbreviated due diligence and summarize all of their analysis in an investment strategy that they pitch to a panel of judges.<ref name="vciccompetition">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/programs/VCIC/ "VCIC Competition"] Retrieved November 6, 2013.</ref>
== Library == In addition to the collections and holdings at the [[Malcolm A. Love Library]], the primary [[academic library]] on the SDSU campus, the Lavin Entrepreneurship Center maintains the ''[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/resources/Library Lavin Entrepreneurship Business Library]'', an extensive entrepreneurship-related library with an indexed collection of over 700 business plans, a state-of-the-art boardroom and numerous affiliations with local and national entrepreneurial organizations.<ref name="lavinentrepreneurshipcenterbusinesslibrary">[http://lavincenter.sdsu.edu/resources/Library "Lavin Entrepreneurship Center Business Library"] Retrieved November 5, 2013.</ref> * EMC Resource Library<ref>http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/dept/emc/resources/Library</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

If there is more than one native name, in different languages, enter those names using {{tl|lang}}, instead. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | former type = | type = | traded_as = | industry = [[Analytics]] | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 2003 | founder = Atul Jalan <ref>{{cite web|title=Atul Crunchbase profile|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/atul-jalan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Atul Mentioned in Siliconindia|url=http://www.siliconindia.com/shownews/Atul_Jalan_founded_Manthan_Systems_raises_15_Million-nid-63086-cid-100.html}}</ref> | defunct = <!-- {{End date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Bangalore]] | location_country = India | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices, etc. --> | area_served = | key_people = | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 500+<ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan profile|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/manthan-systems#/entity|publisher=CrunchBase}}</ref> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|https://www.manthan.com/}} | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }}
'''Manthan''' is a [[business intelligence]] and [[analytics]] company with headquarters in [[Bangalore]], [[India]] which employs more than 500 people and has been listed by [[Frost & Sullivan]] at the 2014 India ICT Awards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Technology Fast 500 Asia Pacific Rankings and CEO Survey|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/jp/Documents/technology-media-telecommunications/fast/jp-fast-fast500-winnersreport-04.pdf}}</ref> as a [[Deloitte Fast 500]] and being named as the "Company of the Year - Analytics"<ref>{{cite web|title=Frost & Sullivan Honors the Best in Indian ICT Industry at the 2014 India ICT Awards|url=http://www.frost.com/prod/servlet/cpo/291232401}}</ref>
==History==
Manthan has received funding from various sources.<ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan Crunchbase Profile|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/manthan-systems#/entity}}</ref> One of its earliest funding rounds, with an investment of $15 million<ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan Systems Secures Series B Financing From Fidelity International, IDG Ventures and DFJ ePlanet Ventures|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/manthan-systems-secures-series-b-financing-from-fidelity-international-idg-ventures-and-dfj-eplanet-ventures-70457952.html}}</ref> was led by [[Fidelity International]] and their recent funding of $60M <ref>{{cite web|title=Data Analytics Startup Manthan Gets $60 Mn In Series D From Temasek & Norwest|url=https://inc42.com/buzz/data-analytics-startup-manthan-gets-60-mn-series-d-temasek-norwest/}}</ref> was led by [[Temasek Holdings]] and [[Norwest Venture Partners]]. Atul Jalan, the founder of Manthan is named as one of the top 10 most influential analytics leaders in India for the year 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=10 Most Influential Analytics Leaders in India – 2015|url=http://www.fractalanalytics.com/news/10-most-influential-analytics-leaders-india-%E2%80%93-2015}}</ref>
==Products== Manthan Systems, a provider of [[business intelligence]] (BI) and analytical [[solution]]s for the retail and consumer packaged goods industries. Manthan develops and markets a suite of software products and synergistic services to global retailers enabling them to take data-driven business decisions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Atul Jalan founded Manthan Systems raises $15 Million|url=http://www.siliconindia.com/shownews/Atul_Jalan_founded_Manthan_Systems_raises_15_Million-nid-63086-cid-100.html}}</ref> In 2016, Manthan announced a partnership with [[Tableau Software]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan Announces Technology Partnership with Tableau Software|url=http://www.nbc-2.com/story/31955655/manthan-announces-technology-partnership-with-tableau-software}}</ref>
==Industry recognition and awards==
Awards include Frost & Sullivan Company of the Year in Analytics - 2016 award,<ref>{{cite web|title=Frost & Sullivan Honors the Best in Indian ICT Industry at the 2014 India ICT Awards|url=http://www.frost.com/prod/servlet/cpo/291232401}}</ref> Winning "Gold in Analytics" at Express IT Awards 2015,<ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan Bags Top Honors in Analytics at Express IT Awards 2015|url=http://techspirit.in/manthan-bags-top-honors-analytics-express-awards-2015/}}</ref> Ranking #1 for Tier 1 retailers in the 2015 RIS Software Leader board,<ref>{{cite web|title=LeaderBoard Part 2: 2015 Winners Revealed|url=http://risnews.edgl.com/retail-insight-blog/LeaderBoard-Part-2--2015-Winners-Revealed103482}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Manthan ranked #1 for Tier 1 retailers in the 2015 RIS Software Leader board|url=http://www.thisweekbangalore.com/manthan-ranked-1-for-tier-1-retailers-in-the-2015-ris-software-leader-board/}}</ref> [[IDG Ventures]] Exceptional Business Growth Award.<ref>{{cite web|title=IDG Ventures Awards Manthan for Exceptional Business Growth|url=http://www.idgvcindia.com/news_port_prweb_11nov_2014.html}}</ref>

{{Eastern Slavic name|Olegovna|Bogdanova}} {{Infobox person |name = Margarita Louis-Dreyfus |image = Margarita Louis-Dreyfus 2011.jpg |caption = Margarita Louis-Dreyfus in 2011. |birth_name = Margarita Olegovna Bogdanova |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|07|01|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]] (now St Petersburg, Russia) |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = Chairman of '''[[Louis Dreyfus Group]]''' |occupation = Businesswoman |education = |alma_mater = |nationality = Swiss | residence = Zurich (Zollikon), Switzerland | salary = | networth = [[US$]]9.5 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (October 2016){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/margarita-louis-dreyfus/|title=Margarita Louis-Dreyfus & family|publisher=}} | spouse = {{marriage|[[Robert Louis-Dreyfus]]
|1992|2009|end=died}} | partner = [[Philipp Hildebrand]] | children = 5 }} '''Margarita Louis-Dreyfus''' (née '''Bogdanova'''; born 1 July 1962) is a Russian-born Swiss [[billionaire]] businesswoman, chairperson of [[Louis Dreyfus Group|Louis Dreyfus]]. ==Early life== Born '''Margarita Olegovna Bogdanova''' ({{lang-ru|Маргарита Олеговна Богданова}}) in [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] (now St Petersburg), she grew up in an orphanage and studied in a trade school as a retail accountant. ==Career== On 29 August 2016, Louis-Dreyfus and the [[Marseille]] mayor, [[Jean-Claude Gaudin]], stated during a press conference with [[Frank McCourt (executive)|Frank McCourt]] that McCourt had agreed in principle to purchase the French [[Ligue 1]] football team, [[Olympique de Marseille]], owned by Louis-Dreyfus. The purchase deal was completed for a reported price tag of 45 million euros on 17 October 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-soccer-marseille-sale-idUSKCN1141JB|title=Former LA Dodgers owner McCourt to buy Marseille|date=29 August 2016|publisher=|via=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/sportsnow/la-sp-frank-mccourt-olympique-de-marseille-20160829-snap-story.html|title=French soccer club thinks Frank McCourt led Dodgers to 'tremendous economic success'|first=Los Angeles|last=Times|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37685865|title=Marseille: Frank McCourt promises £180m investment after buying Ligue 1 club|publisher=BBC|date=17 October 2016}} ==Personal life== In 1988, on a Zurich to London flight, she met [[Robert Louis-Dreyfus]]. They married in 1992 and had three sons.{{cite web|url=http://madame.lefigaro.fr/societe/margarita-louis-dreyfus-tsarine-affaires-270713-440620 |title=Margarita Louis-Dreyfus, la tsarine des affaires - Madame Figaro |language=fr |website=Madame.lefigaro.fr |date= |accessdate=2017-02-23}} Margarita, who had been working for a circuit-board equipment seller, became a full-time wife and mother.{{cite news|last1=Katz|first1=Alan|title=Louis-Dreyfus Widow Chairman Ousts Men Running Commodities Giant|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-01-31/louis-dreyfus-widow-ousts-men-running-commodities-giant-as-newest-chairman.html|accessdate=10 November 2014|work=Bloomberg|date=31 January 2012}} She took over as chairman of the [[Louis Dreyfus Group]] in 2009, following her husband's death from leukemia.{{cite web|title=Margarita Louis-Dreyfus|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/margarita-louis-dreyfus/|website=Forbes|accessdate=10 November 2014}} In 2016, she had a net worth of $9.5 billion. She is a Swiss citizen living in Zurich with her three sons (Éric born in 1992, and twins, Maurice and Kyril, born in 1998), according to ''[[Forbes]]''. Her partner is [[Philipp Hildebrand]], the former head of the Swiss central bank.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-01-04/louis-dreyfus-chairwoman-pregnant-with-twins-at-53-plans-leave|website=Bloomberg Business|title=Louis Dreyfus Chairwoman, Pregnant With Twins, Plans Leave|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=4 January 2016}} She gave birth to twin girls on 21 March 2016.{{cite web|title=Margarita Louis-Dreyfus gives birth to twins|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/21/swiss-billionaire-margarita-louis-dreyfus-birth-twins-53|accessdate=21 March 2016}} Margarita is the second cousin (by marriage) of American actress [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Louis-Dreyfus, Margarita}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swiss billionaires]] [[Category:Female billionaires]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:Louis-Dreyfus family|Margarita]] [[Category:Moscow State University alumni]] [[Category:Russian emigrants to France]] [[Category:People from Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Soviet women]] [[Category:Russian women in business]] [[Category:Swiss chairmen of corporations]] [[Category:Women corporate directors]] [[Category:Swiss women in business]] [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Olympique de Marseille]] [[Category:Russian corporate directors]] [[Category:20th-century Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Swiss businesspeople]] {{Switzerland-business-bio-stub}}

The '''Marketing Hall of Fame''' was launched by the members of the New York chapter of the [[American Marketing Association]], the creators of the [[Effies]] and the GreenBook.
Honorees are inducted in a ceremony held in [[New York City]] every spring.
==Inductees in the Marketing Hall of Fame==
===2014=== [[Beth Comstock]], Senior Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer, [[General Electric]];<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2014">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2014 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2014-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> Dr. [[Philip Kotler]], S.C. Johnson & Son Distinguished Professor of International Marketing, [[Kellogg School of Management]], [[Northwestern University]];<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2014">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2014 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2014-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> [[Joseph V. Tripodi]], Executive Vice President, Chief marketing & Commercial Officer, [[The Coca-Cola Company]]<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2014">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2014 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2014-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref>
===2015=== [[David Aaker]], Vice-Chairman of Prophet Brand Strategy and Professor Emeritus of Marketing Strategy at the [[Haas School of Business]], [[University of California, Berkeley]];<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2015">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2015 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2015-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> [[Yvon Chouinard]], Founder of [[Patagonia]];<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2015">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2015 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2015-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> [[Trevor Edwards]], President, Nike Brand, [[Nike, Inc.]];<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2015">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2015 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2015-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> [[Shelly Lazarus]], Chairman Emeritus, [[Ogilvy & Mather]]<ref name="Marketing Hall of Fame 2015">{{cite web |title=Marketing Hall of Fame 2015 Inductees|url=http://www.marketinghalloffame.org/2015-inductees/|publisher=New York American Marketing Association |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref>
===2016=== [[Al Ries]], Marketing Strategist and Author ; [[Bob Greenberg]], Founder, Chairman/CEO ; John Hayes, Former Chief Marketing Officer, [[American Express]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Adamson |first=Allen |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/allenadamson/2016/03/09/how-2016-marketing-hall-of-fame-winners-al-ries-bob-greenberg-and-john-hayes-have-changed-marketing/#5c25110179d0 |title=How 2016 Marketing Hall Of Fame Winners Al Ries, Bob Greenberg And John Hayes Have Changed Marketing |work=[[Forbes]] |date=2016-03-31 |accessdate=2016-03-09 }}</ref><ref>https://lbbonline.com/news/american-marketing-association-announces-2017-marketing-hall-of-fame-inductees/</ref>
===2017=== [[Seth Godin]], Author, teacher, entrepreneur; [[Lee Clow]], Creative Director, [[TBWA]] Chiat Day ; Esther Lee, Chief Marketing Officer, [[MetLife]]. <ref>http://www.nbc-2.com/story/37859914/tbwas-lee-clow-author-seth-godin-and-metlifes-esther-lee-inducted-into-american-marketing-association-new-york-marketing-hall-of-fame</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = McGill Executive Institute | logo = MEI logo.tiff | logo_size = 260px | type = Not for Profit | foundation = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada ({{Start date|1956}}) | location_city = Montreal, Quebec | location_country = [[Canada]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Professor Louis Gialloreto, Executive Director | industry = [[Executive Education]] | products = Management Seminars, Custom Business Solutions | owner = [[McGill University]] | num_employees = | parent = [[Desautels Faculty of Management]] | homepage = [http://www.executive.mcgill.ca/ www.executive.mcgill.ca] }} The '''McGill Executive Institute''' is the corporate education and management development unit of the [[McGill University]] [[Desautels Faculty of Management]] in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada. It provides a variety of public business seminars as well as custom [[executive education]] and coaching for all levels of management. Founded in 1956,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QokxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=naUFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=1308%2C2644596 McGill Management Institute teaches the unusual...it’s where executives go to learn about computers], The Montreal Gazette, Aug 18, 1984, Retrieved on August 7, 2010 the Institute has a full-time staff of learning design and program managers working with professors at McGill’s Faculties of Management, Law, Arts, Education and Medicine, external guest experts in specific fields, as well as visiting professors from universities worldwide. The Institute’s clientele includes businesses, not-for-profit organizations and government/public sector services. ==History== After establishing the first management diploma in 1906, McGill University began offering evening classes in business education in 1912.[https://www.mcgill.ca/study/2010-2011/sites/mcgill.ca.study.2010-2011/files/desautels_faculty_of_management_201011_0.pdf Desautels Faculty of Management: Programs, Courses and University Regulations 2010-2011], Desautels Website, PDF retrieved on August 9, 2010 Following Canada's post World War II expansion, McGill University responded to the needs of senior executives by offering seminars in personnel management, marketing, and finance.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EIMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dpkFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20personnel-management&pg=3548%2C915652 McGill University Evening Extension Course listing], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 8, 1950, Retrieved on August 9, 2010 Concurrent to business seminars offered by McGill, the Executive Development Institute, a private business education organization, began to offer the Executive Development Course (EDC) in 1949, in affiliation with the [[Montreal Board of Trade]]. It was developed with support from the Graduate School of Business at [[Harvard University]].[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vJgtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kZ0FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=3255%2C552133 Executive Development Institute, 12th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 5, 1961, Retrieved on August 11, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aMItAAAAIBAJ&sjid=d54FAAAAIBAJ&dq=montreal%20board-of-trade%20seminar%20institute%20executive&pg=4026%2C1105140 Executive Development Institute, 13th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 7, 1962, Retrieved on August 11, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W8MtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_Z4FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=1953%2C316811 Executive Development Institute, 15th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Aug 3, 1964, Retrieved on August 11, 2010 A precursor to the existence of many MBA and later EMBA programs, the EDC was designed to provide a comprehensive look at management practices in strategy, human resources, marketing, negotiations and financial acumen.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kZMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j54FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=3272%2C1782776 To Help the Executive Grow], The Montreal Gazette - Jul 11, 1963, Retrieved on August 11, 2010 In 1956, the McGill Management Institute was founded to facilitate the more effective delivery of business seminars offered at McGill University. In 1973, the Executive Development Institute merged with the McGill Management Institute and, under the McGill banner, continued the facilitation of the EDC.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UhQyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3qEFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=1486%2C4031929 Ross Plans Book on University Growth], The Montreal Gazette - Aug 31, 1973, Retrieved on August 7, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zYcxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uKEFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=5535%2C2565363 Psychological Survival for Executives], The Montreal Gazette - April 10, 1974, Retrieved on August 9, 2010 The merger coincided with a move to its current home in the Bronfman building at McGill University on Sherbrooke Street in Montreal, where it underwent a significant expansion of its offerings. By 1984, the McGill Management Institute was offering 70 day-time seminars and 20 evening courses each year, in addition to the EDC. In 1993, the McGill Management Institute was renamed the McGill International Executive Institute. It took its current name, the McGill Executive Institute, in 2002. It is a division of the [[Desautels Faculty of Management]]. ==Philosophy== The McGill Executive Institute has been noted for its approach to action-based learning,[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 213, Retrieved on September 9, 2010 as well as for its international dimension. In his 2009 work, ''Executive Education in Canadian Firms'', Bruce Gordon R. Fowler states the following:
The executive programs at this Institute recognize better than most schools, even among the other eight illustrious institutions discussed here, the need for international diversity and content. Indeed, McGill has been recognized as having an international dimension unsurpassed in North America for diversity among students and faculty, and for program style and content. The scope of McGill's global outlook is certainly equal to that of Harvard and INSEAD, also featured here as giants of international connectivity, which simply must be part of any program involving executives of international or multinational firms.[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 138, Retrieved on September 9, 2010
==Products and Services== Each year, the McGill Executive Institute provides approximately 20 to 40 open enrolment seminars addressing a number of business topics. The Institute’s longest running program is the Executive Development Course which was launched in 1949. The EDC has been expanded over the years, and is currently offered in three successive modules: the Executive Development Course, the Advanced Management Course, and Integrated Management Thinking. Together, these are referred to by the Institute as the [[Mini-MBA]] Series.[http://executive.mcgill.ca/seminars List of Seminars available from McGill Executive Institute website], Retrieved on September 9, 2010 The McGill Executive Institute also designs and delivers customized learning solutions specifically for an organization’s team of managers or executives. Services range from short workshops delivered in English, French or bilingual formats to global initiatives with delivery of modules to participants across management levels over several years. The McGill Executive Institute also offers an International Masters in Practicing Management (IMPM), as well as the Advanced Leadership Program (ALP). These longer, global programs occur over several modules and across multiple international locations, in conjunction with other universities: The Indian Institute of Management in Bangalore, India; Lancaster University in the UK; Korea Development Institute School of Public Policy and Management in Seoul, Korea; and INSEAD in France. Both the ALP and the IMPM were co-founded and are co-directed by Professor [[Henry Mintzberg]].[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 135, Retrieved on September 9, 2010 ==Faculty and Guest Speakers== Well-known McGill faculty members include Professor [[Henry Mintzberg]] on advanced leadership issues and Professor Nancy Adler on [[organizational behavior]]. Recent guest speakers of note have included business leaders [[Daniel Lamarre]], [[Larry Smith (Canadian football)|Larry Smith]], Jim Cherry, Alan Allnutt, Paul Côté and [[Pierre Boivin]]. ==Partners and Collaborators== The McGill Executive Institute partners with the [[Institute of Corporate Directors]] (ICD) in Canada to deliver the Director’s Education Program. It is also a registered education provider with the [[Project Management Institute]] (PMI) and collaborates with the Canadian Corporate Counsel Association to deliver development programs for lawyers on financial literacy. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.executive.mcgill.ca/ McGill Executive Institute] * [https://www.mcgill.ca/ McGill University] [[Category:McGill University]] [[Category:Business education]]

Monopolistc competition models are used under the rubric of [[imperfect competition]] in International Economics. This model is a derivative of the [[monopolistic competition]] model that is part of basic economics. Here it is tailored to international trade.
==Setting up the model== Monopolies are not often found in practice, the more usual market format is [[oligopoly]]: several firms, each of whom is big enough that a change in their price will affect the price of the other firms, but none with an unchallenged monopoly. When looking at oligopolies the problem of ''interdependence'' arises. Interdependence means that the firms will, when setting their prices, consider the effect this price will have on the actions of both consumers and competitors. For their part, the competitors will consider their expectations of the firm's response to any action they may take in return. Thus, there is a complex game with each side "trying to second guess each others' strategies."<ref>Krugman, Paul, and Maurice Obstfeld. ''International Economics: Theory and Policy,'' 7th ed. (Boston: Pearson Addison-Wesley, 2005) pg 116.</ref> The Monopolistic Competition model is used because its simplicity allows the examination of one type of oligopoly while avoiding the issue of interdependence.
==Benefits of the model== The appeal of this model is not its closeness to the real world but its simplicity. What this model accomplishes most is that it shows us the benefits to trade presented by [[economies of scale]].
==Assumptions of the model== *1. Each firm is presumed to be able ''differentiate its product'' from that of its rivals. Cars are a good example here; they are very different, yet in direct competition with each other. This means there will be some customer loyalty, which allows for some flexibility for the firm to move to a higher price. In other words, not all of a firm's customers would leave for other products if the firm raised its prices. *2. This model dismisses the issue of interdependence when a firm sets its price. The firm will act ''as if it were a monopoly'' regarding the price it sets, not considering the potential responses from its competitors. The justification is that there are numerous firms in the market, so each receives only scant attention from the others. ===Background of the model=== :*An industry consisting of a number of firms, each of which produces differentiated products. The firms are monopolists for their products, but depend somewhat of the number of reasonable alternatives available and the price of those alternatives. Each firm within the industry thus faces a demand that is effected by the price and prevalence of reasonable alternatives. :*Generally we expect a firm's sales to increase the stronger the total demand for the industry's product as a whole. Conversely, we expect the firm to sell less if there are a significant number of firms in the industry and/or the higher the firm's price in relation to those competitors. The demand equation for such a firm would be:
:::::::::::'''Q = ''S'' x [1/n - ''b'' x (P - ''P'')]'''
:::* "Q" = the firm's sales. "''S''" is the total sales of the industry. "n" is the number of firms in the industry, "''b''" is a constant term representing the responsiveness of a firm's sales to its price. "P" is the price charged by the firm itself. "''P''" is the average price charged by its competitors. :::* The intuition of this model is: ::::* If all firms charge the same price their respective market share will be 1/n. Firms charging more get less, firms charging less get more. :::::*(Note) Assume that lower prices will not bring new consumers into the market. In this model consumers can only be gained at the expense of other firms. This simplifies things, allowing a focus on the competition among firms and also allows the assumption that if ''S'' represents the market size, and the firms are charging the same price, the market share of each firm will be ''S''/n.
==Notes== {{Portal|Economics}} <references/>

{{Infobox Politician (general) | name= Parmanand Singh | image= | imagesize= | title= Member of Legislative Council for Northern & Western Division | term_start= 1929 | term_end= 1929 | predecessor= | successor= | title2= | term_start2= | term_end2= | predecessor2= | successor2= | title3= | term_start3= | term_end3= | predecessor3= | successor3= | title4= | term_start4= | term_end4= | predecessor4= | successor4= | birth_date= 1905 | birth_place= [[Ba Province|Ba, Fiji]] | death_date= | death_place= | party= | residence= | spouse= | profession= Businessman | footnotes= }}
'''Parmanand Singh''' (born 1905) was one of the three [[Indo-Fijians]] elected to the [[Legislative Council of Fiji|Legislative Council]] of [[Fiji]] in October 1929 when Indo-Fijians were given the first opportunity to elect their own representatives. The other two were [[Vishnu Deo]] and [[James Ramchandar Rao]]. Singh was a landlord from Ba and undertook several business ventures which included publishing newspapers.
==Biography== Parmanand Singh was born in [[Yalalevu]] in the [[Ba District, Fiji|Ba District]] of Fiji in 1905. His parents had come to Fiji as [[Indian indenture system|indentured labourer]]s and prospered in the opportunities available after indenture. He was educated at [[Auckland]] College, graduating in 1923. While in [[New Zealand]], he played rugby, a game rarely played by Fiji Indians.
On his return to Fiji, he took advantage of a business opportunity by leasing land from [[Colonial Sugar Refining Company (Fiji)|Colonial Sugar Refining Company]] (CSR) and sub-leasing it to small farmers.
Like most rich farmers from Ba, he joined the [[Arya Samaj in Fiji|Arya Samaj]] and was chosen by [[Vishnu Deo]] to contest the Northern & Western Division in the [[1929 Fijian general election|1929 general elections]], the first in which Indo-Fijians were allowed to vote.<ref>[http://fijielections.blogspot.com/2017/02/fiji-legislative-council-election-1929.html 1929 Fiji Legislative Council elections] Fiji Elections</ref> He won easily with the support of Deo and the Arya Samaj, an organisation to which most educated Fiji Indians belonged. However, two weeks after being sworn in he and the two other Indo-Fijians representatives resigned when a motion asking for equal political rights for Indo-Fijians was defeated.
He was opposed to the immigration of [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]]s and [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]]s, a cause later taken up by his brother, [[Chattur Singh]] who was later also a member of the Legislative Council.
In 1948, he left for [[India]] for the education of his children and returned 3 years later.
He saw opportunities in the printing industry and established a printing press in [[Ba (town)|Ba]], which he used to publish a newspaper, ''Awaaz'' (The Voice) in the [[Hindi]] language. He was unable to keep the newspaper in circulation due to a natural disaster and poor staff. He then moved to [[Lautoka]] and in 1956, started publishing another newspaper, ''Jai Fiji'', which remained in circulation until 1980.<ref>{{cite book| last = Sharma | first = Guru Dayal | title = Memories of Fiji: 1887 - 1987 | publisher =Guru Dayal Sharma, Suva, Fiji | year = 1987 | pages = 151–152 | id = }}</ref>
The family involvement in Fijian politics has continued with his son, [[Anand Singh]], also serving in the [[House of Representatives of Fiji|House of Representatives]] and [[Senate of Fiji|Senate]] and as the [[Attorney General of Fiji]] in the [[Fiji Labour Party]] government of [[Mahendra Chaudhry]] from 1999 to 2000.
== References == {{reflist}}

[[File:Banyuls coast 1 Luc Viatour.jpg|thumb|right|Paulilles]] '''Paulilles''' is a [[protected area]] on the Mediterranean Sea, located between the towns of [[Port-Vendres]], and [[Banyuls-sur-Mer]] in [[Pyrénées-Orientales]], [[North Catalonia]], France.
== History ==
=== The Dynamite Factory === Paulilles Recreational Park occupies a rehabilitated [[dynamite]] factory site protected as an [[ecological network]] by the [[Natura 2000]] European organisation. Originally serving as the French [[Alfred Nobel|Nobel]] Dynamite Factory, it was created by Nobel's associate in France, Paul François Barbe, and built in 1870.<ref>http://histoireduroussillon.free.fr/Villages/Histoire/Paulilles.php</ref> Several accidents over the years caused multiple deaths: the most important ones killed 20 workers in 1882<ref>Article in ''Le Républicain des Pyrénées Orientales'', 26 January 1882</ref> and 5 in 1885.<ref>Fabricio Cardenas, [http://vieuxpapierspo.blogspot.fr/2015/07/explosion-paulilles-en-1885.html Vieux papiers des Pyrénées-Orientales, ''Explosion à Paulilles en 1885 ''], 6 July 2015</ref>
=== Protecting the environment === In July 1991, the installations were closed by the Société nationale des poudres et des explosifs (SNPE), and later sold to the [[Conservatoire du littoral]] in 1998 to protect the area from real estate developers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.conservatoire-du-littoral.fr/front/process/Content.asp?rub=8&rubec=108&site=1990 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090614082531/http://www.conservatoire-du-littoral.fr/front/process/Content.asp?rub=8&rubec=108&site=1990 |archivedate=2009-06-14 |df= }}</ref> In 2005, the [[General Council of the Pyrénées-Orientales]] launched the renovation to ready 9 buildings, destroy nearly 70, and landscape 17 hectares to turn Paulilles into a free and ecological recreational park, a museum on the [[industrial heritage]] of the factory and a traditional Catalan boat repair facility [https://web.archive.org/web/20090225032932/http://www.cg66.fr/environnement/espaces_naturels/paulilles/index.html].<ref>http://www.cete-aix.fr/imgarea/Cotita_9_Paulilles_oct2008_COCHE_INCA.pdf</ref> Paulilles opens to the public in June 2008.
== Geography == [[File:Posidonia 2 Alberto Romeo.jpg|thumb|[[Posidonia]]]] Paulilles is located about 2 miles (3 km) south of [[Port-Vendres]] behind the '''Las Portas pass''' along the scenic [[Route Départementale 914]]. It is a small scale Mediterranean bay, forming a prairie down to the sea between the '''Béar cape''', and the '''Oullestrell cape''' and forms three beaches: '''Bernardi''', '''del Mitg''', '''Fourat''' separated by small cliffs in the bay. The original forest has been well preserved and is typical of the [[Mediterranean region]]. It is composed of [[Aleppo pine]] (Pinus halepensis), [[Maritime Pine]] (Pinus pinaster), [[Stone Pine]] (Pinus pinea), for the [[Pinaceae]])family. Also [[Holm oak]] (Quercus ilex), [[Cork Oak]] (Quercus suber) and [[Olive]] trees (Olea europaea). Local flora is well represented with the [[Armeria]] of Roussillon (Armeria ruscinonensis Girard), the polycarpon of Catalonia (Polycarpon polycarpoides), the [[Thymelaea]] hirsuta, the Limonium tremolsii, and also [[Tamarix]] ([[Tamaricaceae]]), and Gattiliers (Vitex agnus-castus).
All the waters around Paulilles are also protected by [[Natura 2000]], for its [[Posidonia oceanica]], a species of [[seagrass]] that is endemic to the Mediterranean Sea and [[Coralline algae]]s that offers shelter and nursing home for the rich aquatic life.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://natura2000.ecologie.gouv.fr/sites/FR9101482.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206192701/http://natura2000.ecologie.gouv.fr/sites/FR9101482.html |archivedate=2008-12-06 |df= }}</ref> This marine plants forms large underwater meadows of high importance to the [[environmental conservation]] of the region.
== Recreational opportunities == * [[Biking]] * [[Hiking]] * [[Walking]] * [[Bird watching]] * [[Human swimming|Swimming]] * [[Scuba diving]]
== See also == {{Portal|Ecology}} * [[Côte Vermeille]] * [[European Route of Industrial Heritage]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{wikisource|Histoire de Paulilles}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100417053735/http://www.conservatoire-du-littoral.fr/front/process/Content.asp?rub=8&rubec=108&site=1990&entite=108 Website of the Conservatoire du littoral] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090225032932/http://www.cg66.fr/environnement/espaces_naturels/paulilles/index.html Presentation of the rehab project by the General Council of Pyrenees Orientales] {{coord|42|30|05|N|3|07|25|E |region:FR_type:landmark |display=title}} *[http://www.cete-aix.fr/imgarea/Cotita_9_Paulilles_oct2008_COCHE_INCA.pdf Detailed architecture information on the rehabilitation of Paulilles]

[[File:Renzo Barbera 1972.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Renzo Barbera, 1972]] '''Renzo Barbera''' ([[Palermo]], 19 April 1920 – [[Palermo]], 20 May 2002) was an [[Italy|Italian]] [[businessman]] and the chairman of Italian football club [[U.S. Città di Palermo]] from 1970 to 1980.<ref>''[http://www.stadionews.it/quindici-anni-senza-presidentissimo-un-uomo-daltri-tempi-manca-al-mondo-del-calcio/ Quindici anni senza Renzo Barbera, un uomo di altri tempi]'' - ''stadionews.it''</ref> He was nicknamed ''"Presidentissimo"'' and ''"The Last [[The Leopard|Leopard]]"''.<ref>''[http://sport.livesicilia.it/2012/05/19/dieci-anni-senza-il-presidentissimo_145550/ Dieci anni senza il presidentissimo]'' - ''livesicilia.it''</ref>
During his presidency the ''"[[rosanero]]"'' team reached two [[Coppa Italia]] finals in 1974 (against [[Bologna F.C. 1909|Bologna]]) and in 1979 (against [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]). After the experience as chairman of Palermo, he was elected president of the Sicilian Organising Committee of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup]]. He died on 20 May 2002 of heart disease.
On 18 September 2002, the Palermo stadium [[Stadio Renzo Barbera|La Favorita]] was renamed as Renzo Barbera.<ref>[http://www.worldsoccer.com/features/stadium-guide/stadium-guide-stadio-renzo-barbera-palermo-369208 ''Stadium Guide: Stadio Renzo Barbera, Palermo''] - ''worldsoccer.com''</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == * Bagnati G., Maggio V., Prestigiacomo V., ''Il Palermo racconta: storie, confessioni e leggende rosanero'' (2004) * Angelini A., ''101 gol che hanno cambiato la storia del calcio italiano'' (2010) * Melati P., Vitale F., ''Vivi da morire'' (2015)

{{Infobox book | name =Saudi Real Estate Companion | image = Saudi Real Estate Companion.jpg | author = H.E. Mueller & A.D. Williams | language = English | country = United States | genre = Business | published =31 March 2016 | publisher = Booktango | isbn = 9781468968934 | exclude_cover = | Saudi Real Estate Companion = }}
'''''Saudi Real Estate Companion''''' is a book edited by H.E. Mueller and A.D. Williams. It focuses on bringing international standards to the market through a focus on all aspects of a standard real estate cycle<ref name=":0" />.
==Overview==
It is one of the first non-Arabic language books covering [[Saudi Arabia|Saudi]] real estate.The book attempts to address a large range of topics covering the best ways to approach real estate investment, marketing, development and valuations. These are approached in a way as to introduce many advanced techniques to the reader using standard (non-technical) language.
The work is divided into seven key sections:<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Saudi-Real-Estate-Companion-Essential-ebook/dp/B01DTNO0SC|title=Saudi Real Estate Companion: Essential Real Estate Skills for the Saudi Arabian Market|last=Mueller|first=H. E.|last2=Williams|first2=A. D.|date=2016-04-04|publisher=Booktango|language=English}}</ref> * [[Valuation (finance)|Valuations]]; covering the basis of valuing different asset types for investment and self-ownership purposes in the Kingdom * Market Skills; covering buying and selling properties and examples of real estate fraud and scams to be avoided * Development and [[Feasibility study|feasibility]]; which covers feasibility and best use studies as well as project financing as well as advanced Saudi Real estate market issues * Property and Facility management; covering details of day to day property management and risk reduction * Trading and investment; covering a wide range of Saudi specific investment issues and different trading strategies that can be adopted in the Kingdom * Economic Issues and Real Estate; this section covers the [[Macroeconomics|macro-economic]] issues impacting the Saudi real estate market as well as real estate cycles in the kingdom * Market and Geographic commentary; considered specific areas in the Kingdom focusing on districts and sectors that are likely to have good potential in each of the major cities such as [[Riyadh]], [[Jeddah]], [[Eastern Province, Saudi Arabia|Eastern Province]] etc.
==Real Estate Cycle==
The authors dedicated a significant portion to rel estate cycles in Saudi Arabia with a focus on historic, economic and psychological factors. At the same time they highlighted the key factor impacting the market as follows:
Oil price fluctuations can make the Saudi property cycle more exaggerated as oil price despite general overall stability over the past few years, can suddenly breakout of its typical range as was seen recently. The current weakness in oil prices which appear to have lasted beyond what was expected, is having an impact on government spending and will in turn impact the real estate market.
However it should be noted that the author denied that this is the case.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/ADwilliamsinKSA|title=AD Williams (@ADwilliamsinKSA) {{!}} Twitter|website=twitter.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-30}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Steen Hildebrandt''' (born in 1944) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] academic and author on [[business]], [[organizational theory]] and [[management]]. He is Professor Emeritus of Management Studies at [[Aarhus School of Business]], [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]] and an associated professor at [[Copenhagen Business School]].<ref name="kd-70">{{cite web | url=http://www.kristeligt-dagblad.dk/mennesker/en-livslang-kamp-mod-human-nedk%C3%B8ling | title=En livslang kamp mod human nedkøling | publisher=[[Kristeligt Dagblad]] | date=22 January 2014 | accessdate=23 September 2016 | author=Poulsen, Marie Louise | language=Danish}}</ref><ref name="jv-festival">{{cite web | url=http://www.jv.dk/artikel/2368492:Haderslev--Festival-med-fokus-paa-miljoe-og-livsstil | title=Festival med fokus på miljø og livsstil | publisher=[[Jydske Vestkysten]] | date=25 August 2016 | accessdate=23 September 2016 | author=Aagaard-Kragh, Christine | language=Danish}}</ref>
==Other pursuits== In 2004 he founded the con sultency Hildebrandt & Brandi in collaboration with Søren Brandi. He was chairman of [[Sankt Lukas Stiftelsen]] in 2007-2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sanktlukas.dk/historisk-overblik/|title=Historick overblik|language=Danish|website=Sankt Lukas Stiftelsen|accessdate=20 March 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Hildebrandt is married and lives in the [[Frederiksberg]] district of Copenahgen. He has two grown-up children.
==Bibliography in English== <!-- {| |- |1998||''The learning organisations: Experiences from Danish enterprises''. (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Lærende organisationer. Erfaringer fra danske virksomheder. |- |2001||''Gold through competence''. (Steen Hildebrandt and Søren Brandi (ed.) Original title in Danish: Kompetenceguldet. |- |2003||''Management by use of diversity''. (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Mangfoldighedsledelse. |- |2005||''Managing the changes''. (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Ledelse af forandring. |- -->
* 1998 ''The learning organisations: Experiences from Danish enterprises.'' (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Lærende organisationer. Erfaringer fra danske virksomheder. * 2001 ''Gold through competence''. (Steen Hildebrandt and Søren Brandi (ed.) Original title in Danish: Kompetenceguldet. * 2003 ''Management by use of diversity''. (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Mangfoldighedsledelse. * 2005 ''Managing the changes''. (with Søren Brandi) Original title in Danish: Ledelse af forandring.

{{POV|talk=NPOV|date=April 2018}} {{Autobiography|talk=NPOV|date=April 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Tammy Barton | image = Tammy May.jpg | alt = Tammy Barton is pictured indoors. She has blonde hair and is wearing a black blazer and a white collared shirt. | caption = Tammy Barton in the MyBudget office in Adelaide | birth_name = Tammy May | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1978|01|27}} | birth_place = | residence = [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] | citizenship = Australia | occupation ={{flat list| * Entrepreneur }} | spouse = Nathan Barton | years_active = 1999–present | imagesize = }} '''Tammy Barton (née May)''' is an Australian entrepreneur and the founder of [[MyBudget]].
== Personal life == '''Tammy Barton (née May)'''
Tammy Barton (née May) is an Australian entrepreneur, businessperson and personal finance expert. She is the founding director of MyBudget,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mybudget.com.au|title=MyBudget|website=|dead-url=}}</ref> a personal budgeting service based in Australia that aims to help people take control of their finances through budgeting and money management.
She has won many awards, including twice being awarded the Telstra Business Woman of the Year (Entrepreneur-South Australia), 2007 and 2017. Barton is recognised as one of Australia's most influential businesswomen<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/news/meet-australias-100-women-of-influence-20121011-jiosz|title=Meet Australia's 100 Women of Influence|last=Hooper, Narelle and Fox|first=Catherine|date=12 October 2012|website=Australian Financial Review|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> and she regularly appears in the media as an expert on personal money management and household budgeting.
== Career == Barton started MyBudget as a home-based business in Adelaide in 1999 at the age of 22 after working at a debt collection agency where she witnessed the damaging effects of financial stress on people.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/business/financial-freedom-just-a-budget-away-20120509-jyzl4|title=Financial freedom just a budget away|website=Australian Financial Review|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/sa-business-journal/south-australian-tammy-mays-mybudget-business-aimed-at-helping-people-budget-is-making-an-impact-in-different-ways/news-story/2dc8b758510104f36de7ca6d9c1fc676|title=South Australian Tammy May's MyBudget business aimed at helping people budget is making an impact in different ways|last=Moss|first=Cory|date=2 March 2004|website=The Advertiser|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> The business has since grown into a national company that employs more than 250 staff in 15 offices across Australia. During that time, the company has delivered its money management services to more than 65,000 clients.
On 26 October 2012, Barton became an appointee to the BankSA Advisory Board. Chairman Rob Chapman said Barton brought "strong credentials and a passionate commitment to helping South Australia prosper and grow".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/new-faces-for-banksa/news-story/fe8c4f9652819cf0257f13806ec45604|title=MyBudget founder Tammy May and former Ernst & Young SA managing partner Mark Butcher join BankSA advisory board|last=Booth|first=Meredith|date=22 October 2012|website=The Advertiser|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> To this day, Barton remains director of and spokesperson for MyBudget.
For her business achievements, Barton has been recognised with a number of awards and honours, see below. During her acceptance speech at the Telstra South Australian Business Woman of the Year Awards in October 2017, Barton announced that MyBudget would be opening its first international branch, in the United Kingdom, in 2018 to further what she described as her "commitment to helping lead the global financial fitness movement.”
== Awards and recognition == Barton has won numerous awards throughout her career including being a two-time winner of the Telstra South Australian Business Woman of the Year Award (2007 and 2017). She has appeared in SmartCompany's list of Australia's Top 30 Female Entrepreneurs in 2015 through to 2017 and was awarded Female Entrepreneur of the Year by the League of Extraordinary Women in 2015.
Summary of awards: * Telstra South Australian Business Woman of the Year Award, 2017 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/business/mybudget-founder-tammy-barton-named-2017-telstra-business-woman-of-the-year/news-story/0ee6457abd89a33a7cbd98359fb521a8|title=MyBudget founder Tammy Barton named 2017 Telstra Business Woman of the Year|last=Griffiths|first=Luke|date=17 October 2017|website=The Advertiser|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> * Smartcompany Australia's Top 30 Female Entrepreneur<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smartcompany.com.au/lists/australias-top-30-female-entrepreneurs-2017/|title="Top 30 Australian female entrepreneurs 2017|last=Koehn|first=Emma et. al.|date=20 November 2017|publisher=Smart Company|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> * League of Extraordinary Women Female Entrepreneur of the Year, 2015, 2016 and 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smartcompany.com.au/people-human-resources/leadership/mybudget-founder-tammy-may-named-female-entrepreneur-of-the-year/|title=MyBudget founder Tammy May named Female Entrepreneur of the Year|last=Keating|first=Eloise|date=26 November 2015|website=SmartCompany|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> * Start Up Daily No 1. Top Female Entrepreneur under 40, 2014<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.startupdaily.net/2014/02/top-50-australian-female-entrepreneurs-under-40/|title=Top 50 Australian Female Entrepreneurs Under 40|website=Startup Daily|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> * Australian Financial Review 100 Women of Influence Awards, 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smartcompany.com.au/entrepreneurs/influencers-profiles/planning-for-the-future-how-tammy-may-created-my-budget/2/|title=Planning for the future: How Tammy May created MyBudget|last=Redrup|first=Yolanda|date=21 November 2013|publisher=Smart Company|dead-url=|access-date=22 November 2017}}</ref> * International Business Times Australia Top 100 Women of Influence, 2012 * Telstra South Australian Business Woman of the Year Award, 2007 * Telstra Business Owner Award, 2007 * Australian Government Business Innovation Award, 2007 * Ernst and Young's Entrepreneur of the Year Finalist, 2008
== References == {{Reflist | colwidth = 30em | refs =[1] www.mybudget.com.au [2] Hooper, Narelle and Fox, Catherine (12 October 2012) "Meet Australia's 100 Women of Influence." Australian Financial Review. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [3] "Financial freedom just a budget away.". Retrieved 22 November 2017. [4] Moss, Corey (3 March 2004). "South Australian Tammy May's MyBudget business aimed at helping people budget is making an impact in different ways." The Advertiser. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [5] Booth, Meredith (22 October 2012) "MyBudget founder Tammy May and former Ernst & Young SA managing partner Mark Butcher join BankSA advisory board." The Advertiser. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [6] Griffiths, Luke (18 October 2017) "MyBudget founder Tammy Barton named 2017 Telstra Business Woman of the Year." The Advertiser. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [7] Koehn, Emma et. al. (20 November 2017) "Top 30 Australian female entrepreneurs 2017." SmartCompany. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [8] Keating, Eloise (26 November 2015) "MyBudget founder Tammy May named Female Entrepreneur of the Year." SmartCompany. Retrieved 22 November 2017. [9] "Top 50 Australian female entrepreneurs under 40."Startup Daily. Retrieved 22 November 2017.
